page.title: 01The Cheviot Hills
page.content: The area is a wild, open expanse of rolling upland. Dominating the skyline of this region is the cheviot (815m) which is clearly visible from afar as a flat pleateau standing above its neighbours. The broad flat top of the cheviot is nearly always waterlogged, even in summer. Most of the surrounding hills have similar poor drainage, and the whole area is covered with peat hags. This is a wild, inhospitable place, where only the hardiest survive. Grouse, sheep and the occasional fox are the natural occupants of this region. The only people likely to be seen apart from a farmer herding a few sheep are fell walkers covering the last few miles of the Pennine Way.For those seeking solitude there are no intrusions by man to disturb the silence of this wild, barren and yet outstandingly
